xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: The authors gratefully acknowledge the full support of the Thailand Research Fund (through the Royal Golden Jubilee Project ; PHD/0304/2550 ), the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) , and the Canada Foundation for Innovation (CFI) . Sincere thanks and appreciation go to the Department of Imaging and Printing Technology, Chulalongkorn University and the Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Waterloo for provision of the research facilities.

organization.$: Department of Rubber Technology and Polymer Science
Green Polymer and Catalysis Technology Laboratory

head.citation-title: Modification of deproteinized natural rubber via grafting polymerization with maleic anhydride
head.abstracts: Modification of natural rubber (NR) via grafting polymerization with maleic anhydride (MA) has received wide attention as it could improve the hydrophilicity of NR and extend its application to a wider application field. However, the grafting efficiency of MA onto NR in either the molten state or solution state is low and is accompanied with undesired high gel content in the grafts. In this work a novel technical route was developed in that a deproteinization operation was conducted before carrying out the grafting process and a differential microemulsion polymerization technique was applied for the grafting reaction. The effects of initiator and monomer concentration, reaction temperature, and reaction time on the grafting efficiency and gel fraction were investigated, and a comparison of the reaction performance was conducted for deproteinized NR (DPNR) and NR. The results indicated that the deproteinization operation could significantly improve the grafting efficiency and reduce the gel content, and a 29% yield of MA grafted onto the rubber backbone could be achieved at a condition of a DPNR:MA:initiator ratio of 85:9:6 (wt%) at 60 C for 8 h. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
